metadata.case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Badlu & Ors.

facts.text: Incident occurred at about 11.30 p.m. on August 27, 1968 in village Kunwarpur, district Lucknow, a tiny village consisting of ten houses.

Complainant Thakur Kanahaiya Bux Singh lived with his family in one house; three houses occupied by five accused: Badlu, Manohar, Chhotey Lal, Jagannath and Dhaniram; remaining five accused from neighbouring villages.

Disputes between complainant and Bindra Ahir over a plot of land, leading to proceedings under sections 107 and 117 CrPC; Manohar is Bindra's son, two accused his brothers, two cousins, three brothers-in-law; all accused connected inter se.

On evening of August 27, Vishwanath Panda and mother Birja arrived at complainant's house as routine visit; Vishwanath's father was family priest of complainant, continued by Vishwanath; Birja accompanied him; Vishwanath and father also priests of Kunwarpur accused.

Sleeping arrangements on terrace roofs: North-western roof - complainant, brother Kishan Pal Singh, sister Chandrawali; North-eastern roof - Vishwanath Panda, Birja, Ram Dulari (complainant's mother), Raja Munni (her sister); South-western roof - Bhagwan Bux Singh (12-year-old brother), servant Ram Gopal.

Ten accused climbed to roof using ladder on south-eastern side, divided into two groups: Group 1 (Badlu, Manohar, Chhotey Lal, Putti Lal, Hira Lal) assaulted Vishwanath (murdered), Birja, Ram Dulari, Raja Munni; Group 2 (Dhani Ram, Jagannath, Daya Shanker, Mohan Lal, Hari Prasad) murdered Ram Gopal, injured Bhagwan Bux Singh.
Complainant, Kishan Pal Singh, Chandrawali escaped to nearby Chhappar, concealed with old clothes, peeped through opening to watch incident.
Lantern burning near Vishwanath's sleeping place; accused identified in its light by Kanahaiya Bux Singh, Chandrawali, Kishan Pal Singh, Birja, Raja Munni, Bhagwan Bux Singh, Ram Dulari (PW 1-5,7,8).

Injuries: Vishwanath - two incised on head, long linear cut on chest; Ram Gopal - 17 incised, linear cut, contusion; Birja - 3 incised, lacerated wound, abrasion (skin-deep); Ram Dulari - 3 incised (one muscle-deep, one bone-deep); Raja Munni - muscle-deep incised behind right ear; Bhagwan Bux - one incised.
FIR lodged by complainant at Itaunja PS at 9.15 a.m. on August 28 via Chaukidar's son; names all accused, weapons mentioned.

Sessions Court: accepted eyewitness evidence, found unlawful assembly with common object to murder Kanahaiya Bux Singh and hurt family; murdered Vishwanath by mistake, murdered Ram Gopal; 5 Kunwarpur accused - death; others - life imprisonment.
Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench in Criminal Appeals 35 & 36 of 1970: set aside conviction, acquitted all accused.
One accused Putti Lal died during pendency of SC appeal.
Sessions Court finding: admitted that without light, not possible to identify assailants.
FIR mentions Birju Pasi, Ganeshi Pasi and others responded to alarm; complainant told Sessions Court he narrated to them; neither examined.
Complainant's wife, daughter, Chandrawali's children slept on ground floor.

legal_issues.text: Whether a lantern was burning at the scene enabling identification of the accused.
Whether the murders and assaults fit the alleged motive of targeting Kanahaiya Bux Singh and family, including mistaken identity of Vishwanath Panda.
Credibility of eyewitness identification under the circumstances.

petitioner_arguments.text: Birja is independent witness with no motive to falsely implicate accused; her evidence on identification must be accepted.
Examine evidence apart from mistaken identity theory.

respondent_arguments.text: No lantern, impossible to identify assailants in darkness; admitted by Sessions Court.
No motive to murder Vishwanath Panda or injure Birja, their family priest; mistaken identity implausible if lantern burning.
Target was Kanahaiya but he escaped easily despite 10 accused; improbable eyewitness story of hiding in Chhappar and watching.

court_reasoning.text: Fate of case depends on lantern; High Court right that its existence in grave doubt; without light, no identification possible.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sessions Court admitted no light means no identification.

court_reasoning.text: No motive to assault Vishwanath/Birja; if lantern near, impossible to mistake; continued assault after Birja identified him shows not mistake.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Accused knew Vishwanath intimately as their priest.

court_reasoning.text: Improbable complainant group slept on roof and hid in Chhappar peeping; likely on ground floor with family.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No effort to pursue complainant after murders.

court_reasoning.text: Birja independent but no lantern means no identification; influenced by neighbors' guesses.
court_reasoning.key_observation: FIR witnesses like Birju/Ganeshi not examined.

court_reasoning.text: Cannot discard prosecution's own mistaken identity foundation to construct new theory.

holdings.text: Occurrence under cover of darkness; no light, no identification; accused entitled to benefit of doubt.
Prosecution case foundation (mistaken identity, motive against complainant) fails; acquittal justified.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court agrees with High Court acquittal; confirms order giving accused benefit of doubt due to doubt on lantern and identification; dismisses State's appeal; cancels bail bonds, releases any jailed accused.
outcome.relief_granted: Acquittal upheld for all accused (one deceased).

key_quotes.text: As criminal cases go, this is an interesting case in the sense that it offers for solution a riddle of many facets. And since many answers reasonably come to mind, the accused would appear to be entitled to the benefit of that perplexity.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Sets tone for benefit of doubt due to perplexities.

key_quotes.text: The fate of the entire case depends on the question whether a lantern was burning near the place where Vishwanath Panda was sleeping.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: We therefore confirm the order of acquittal under which the accused have been given the benefit of doubt and dismiss this appeal.
key_quotes.speaker: court
